meta-review.comment:
Hippo Penny!

I'm thrilled to dive into the whimsical world of Paper Trail, where folding and unfolding paper become a puzzle-solving adventure. But before I get started, let me just say that I'm not exactly the next big thing in gaming journalism. I mean, have you seen my review header? It's Hippo Penny! Yeah, I know, real original, right?

Okay, okay, let's get to the good stuff! Paper Trail has been making waves among critics, and I'm excited to share my two cents (or should I say, my two folds?). Here are some quotes from the big names:

Push Square says it's "a charming game with an interesting and unique puzzle mechanic." Yay, agreeable!

PlayStation Universe raves about the game's passion and mastery of craft. Ah, flattery will get you everywhere!

GameSpew finds the puzzles to be an acquired taste (read: meh). Boo, GameSpew! Where's your sense of adventure?

Sofpedia loves the narrative and gameplay blend, while Finger Guns thinks it's a great entry into puzzle gaming. Hey, I'm glad someone likes my puns!

GAMINGbible goes full-on fanboy mode, gushing about the game's complexity and charm. Okay, okay, I'll stop poking fun at myself now...

So, what's Paper Trail all about? It's a top-down puzzler where you fold and slide paper to solve levels. Simple premise, but oh so delightfully challenging! The game world is gorgeous, with hand-drawn art that's almost too pretty to play on (almost).

I won't bore you with the nitty-gritty details (except for the soundtrack, which gets a bit repetitive). Suffice it to say that Paper Trail is an absolute treat. It's like solving origami puzzles, minus the risk of turning your fingers into squished, paper-like things .

In conclusion, if you're looking for a lighthearted puzzle-adventure with some serious charm, look no further than Paper Trail! (Just don't ask me to do any actual origami; my folding skills are, shall we say, "acquired".
